title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The Federal Reserve System determines amendments regarding the authority to offer demand deposit accounts, with an effective date set for 2 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits under various acts and requirement for joint rulemaking within 2 years. The text chunk discusses authorizing the payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions subject to regulation, with regulations required to establish scope, types of accounts, limitations, exceptions, and effective date within 2 years. The text authorizes the payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions subject to regulation. The effective date of the amendments is within 2 years of enactment or when final regulations are issued. Definitions for terms like "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency" are provided. The text authorizes the payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The amendment allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at Federal Reserve Banks, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The Board may issue regulations on earnings payments and distribution to these institutions. The depository institutions can earn interest on balances maintained at Federal Reserve Banks, with payments tied to short-term interest rates. Regulations may be issued on earnings payments and distribution to these institutions. The term 'depository institution' includes various types of institutions such as trust companies, corporations organized under specific sections, and branches of foreign banks. Amendments are made to the Federal Reserve Act regarding member banks and technical adjustments. Amendments are made to the Federal Reserve Act regarding member banks and technical adjustments, including redesignating subparagraphs and updating subsection references. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The text discusses the treatment of escrow accounts in real estate transactions, including the forbearance of fees by depository institutions and any benefits to the account holder resulting from their actions.
